never a
job and even with

many

admitted and so that's the reason for me

I was just so tired I was tired of the

we sat down and we decided and we target

but then there was a higher power than I
there was a love for the city that I

a city that pulled my heart back into

months I had this passion to implement
some radical
policing and so now over the next 19
months I shifted and I transcended from
being a drug
Sergeant ready to retire as a drug

Commander District commander of the
worst District in Baltimore City we call
it the eastern district the most violent
District the most poverished District
46% unemployment in that District
National rating at that time National
rating the AIDS and the tuberculosis was

little
neighborhood and I said you know what we

and so in order to bring change that I

felt in my heart I had to start
listening to that inner
spirit I had to start listening to that

everything that I had been trained to do
but we still did it we still did it cuz
we listened to that inner spirit because
I realized if I was to see real police
reform in the communities that I had
authority over for Public Safety and so
we had to change our stinking
thinking we had to change it and so what
we did is we started to think
holistically and not
paramilitar so we thought
differently and we started to realize
that it could never be and never should

decided to come to that intersection
where I could meet all classes all Races
all Creed all color where I would meet
the businesses and I would meet the
faith base and I would meet the Eds the
meds and I would meet all people that
made up the communities that I had
authority over and so I met them and I
began to listen see police have a
problem often time we want to bring
things into the community we want to
come up with these extravagant
strategies and deployments but we never
talk to the community about them and we
shove them into the community and say
take
that but we said we got to get rid of
that thinking thinking and so we started
talking to our communities and said you
know what this is your community table
we're going to pull up a chair and we
want to hear from you what's going to
work in your community and then some
great things started to happen see
here's the thing I had to figure out a
way to shift 130 cops that were under my
toolage from being occupiers of
communities to being
Partners I had to figure out how to do
that because here's the here's the crazy
thing in law enforcement we have evolved

arm so much so very much it's if if I
was a natural police

beautiful 23inch
arm man it's pretty ain't it it's cut

just look
good that's a great arm protection
that's who we are but we've exercised so
much sometimes that it has has led to

and dehumanized us and we forgotten the
Mantra across this nation is to protect
and serve some y'all don't know that
protect and
serve so you look at the other arm and
then you you look at it and there it
is you know it's kind it's kind of it's
kind of weak it looks
sickly it's withering and it's
dying because we have invested so much

our mothers and our fathers and so
somehow along the way somehow along the

because we are proud
profession it is very hard for us to

it's even harder to make a

just a law enforcement
because every one of us makes up a

and as communities can I say this we
have put too much responsibility on law

much and then we have the audacity and
the nerve to get upset with law
enforcement when we take
action there's no way in the
world that we as a community should be
calling the police
for kids playing ball in the

should be calling the police because my

his dog came over to my yard and did a
number two and a number one there's no
way we should be calling the
police but we have surrendered so much
of our responsibility so much of the
listen when I was a little boy coming up
in Baltimore and listen we played rough
in the street I ain't never see a police
come and break us
up you know who came it was the elders
it was the parental figures in the
community it was those Guardians it was
that Village mentality they came and
said stop that and do this and stop that
we had mentors throughout all of the

us and I even listen I even and when I
say community I'm talking about
everything that makes up the community
even listen because I'm a preacher I
listen I'm very hard on the churches
because I believe the churches too often
have become Mia missing an action I
believe they have shifted over the last
10 20 years from being community

door around the corner and you in church
they shifted from that and they became
commuter
churches and so you now have churches
who have become Disconnected by default
from the very Community where they're
planted and they don't take care of that

really need to wrap this up community
and policing we've all lost that
precious gift and I call it relational
Equity we've lost it with one another
it's not somebody else's fault it's all
of our fault we all take responsibility
in this but I say this it's not too late
for all of us to build our cities and
this nation to make it great again it is
never too late it is never too late do

three years in after putting Pastors in

you know you be getting in out of the

back we began to deal with our youth we

on the wrong side of fence we knew that
we had an economic problem so we began

didn't have access to proper Medicare so
we partner up we got to that

thinking about the crime because at the
end of the
day if we took care of the needs of the

cause the crime will take care of

and
so after 3 years of a 4 and a half year

homicides everything have dropped down
back to the 1970s and it might go back

crime low so much so I had other

we got to get some of that we got to get
some of
that and so we gave him some of that
and in a short period of time the city
went to a 30-year crime load for the

and we celebrated because we had learned

service first but I got to tell you this
these last few
years as much as we had learned to

and great relational police officers
rather than reactive these last years
have disappointed
me they have broken my heart the
uprising still
hurts it still hurts my heart because
truly I believe that it should have
never
happened I believe it should have never

listen I'm excited about Baltimore today

that we will be great
again I
